entry.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the security concerns associated with the ECDSA R value during the signing process in the context of quantum computing threats to Bitcoin. The ECDSA R value, crucial for the signature, can be arbitrarily chosen by the signer. This introduces a vulnerability where a quantum attacker might exploit this by committing any selected post-quantum (PQ) signature data when executing a spend. Jameson Lopp highlights a significant issue that, in the event of a Cryptographically Relevant Quantum Computer (CRQC) emergence, it becomes challenging for third-party nodes to verify the legitimacy of transactions unless the output script has proactively committed to a post-quantum public key. This implies that without such a commitment, the authenticity of spends post-CRQC revelation remains questionable.
Lopp suggests that to mitigate such risks and ensure transaction validation remains reliable in the advent of quantum computing capabilities, UTXO holders need to undertake a proactive migration towards incorporating commitments to PQ public keys within their output scripts. This action is essential for maintaining the integrity and trustworthiness of transactions against the backdrop of evolving quantum computational power.
